I would like to thank both the school and the people who were on the local Centenary of Federation committee for choosing this project and a couple of other projects that will be opening in my electorate in the next few weeks. I would like to thank particularly Kevin Stewart, the chairman of the committee, who put in a lot of time assessing the various applications that the committee received. I think this is one of the most important projects that the committee oversaw.

talk.start.para: —Over the last week or so we have seen the Labor Party pontificating on petrol prices in the hypocritical, political, opportunistic way that we all expect. A party which has no policies to offer has little alternative but to whinge, carp and try to score a couple of points in the media.

speech.para: As the Australian newspaper pointed out, the most puzzling part of this whole petrol issue is why the Queensland Premier, Peter Beattie, wants the whole of Australia to know what a complete fool he is. No Labor Party leader in the country has been more embarrassingly hypocritical about it than `petrol tax Pete'. He has been breathtaking. As we all know, the state governments receive every cent of the GST revenue, including any increase in revenue as a result of higher petrol prices. So as Mr Beattie grandstands on the issue, he is secretly counting the cash in his Treasury coffers. Of course, this is the same Premier who, just a month or so ago, tried to rip millions of dollars off Queensland motorists by slashing the state government petrol subsidy, thereby increasing petrol prices by more than 8c a litre. Now he has the nerve to try to blame the federal government for skyrocketing world oil prices. The fact is that the federal government does not see a skerrick of the money from higher petrol prices because the fuel excise remains the same, no matter what the price. The only winners from rising petrol prices are state governments like Mr Beattie's.

One week ago, I publicly called on Mr Beattie to live up to his rhetoric and divert a percentage of his government's GST revenue towards topping up the fuel subsidy for the state's motorists. It is all very well to jump in front of the nearest TV camera and try to grab a headline, but if you do not have the courage of your convictions, then it is nothing but empty grandstanding from a self-confessed media tart.

Of course, this challenge to replace his whingeing with action was met with a stony silence. To date, he still refuses to give up one brass razoo of the extra petrol tax he is getting. But all of Mr Beattie's brazen hypocrisy and empty point scoring pales in comparison to the whopper he came out with yesterday in the Gold Coast Bulletin. Mr Beattie tried to palm off the full cost of the most important road infrastructure program on the Gold Coast, the Tugun bypass—a road which he promised to deliver if elected—to the federal government. What could his justification possibly be for doing this, besides the obvious media headline? According to Mr Beattie, the federal government will get a revenue windfall from rising petrol prices. Never mind that every single cent of that revenue goes to the states. Never mind that Mr Beattie has already refused to use that money to ease the burden on motorists. And never mind that the Tugun bypass is a road which the state government has sole responsibility for building.

In fact, Mr Beattie's ridiculous comments have unwittingly revealed that Gold Coast residents will never see the Tugun bypass under the current Labor administration. Mr Beattie's comments were a sly trick to create a loophole that will get him out of funding a road that he never had any intention of delivering. Instead of taking the blame for it himself, he tries to pass the buck to the federal government. This is despite the fact that he signed a heads of government agreement with the New South Wales government on 27 March this year which acknowledges that the bypass is solidly a state government project. However, because the federal government recognises how essential this road is for Gold Coast residents and for our local tourism industry, we agreed to bail the Queensland government out and contributed a multi-million dollar funding package to get construction under way.

But not even this is enough for the Premier. Clearly, the only way that the Gold Coast will ever see the Tugun bypass is if the federal government steps in. So I have decided to act on Mr Beattie's suggestion about using increased petrol revenue to fund this road. I will be approaching the transport minister to ask him to withhold the extra petrol money that he would normally hand over to the Queensland government and instead divert it towards funding the Tugun bypass. Surely, Mr Beattie will have no problem with this solution, considering his vocal objections to any government reaping more money from petrol. Surely, he will agree with this solution if he really considers the Tugun bypass to be a priority project.

In fact, Mr Beattie's latest political stunt is a cruel joke on the people of Currumbin. Their local member, Merri Rose, who also happens to be the Queensland tourism minister, has done nothing but stand by and watch it happen. But the people of the southern Gold Coast will not forget the Beattie Labor government's deceit and trickery when it comes to the next election. I can assure the Labor Party that I will make sure of that.

subdebateinfo.title: Petrol Prices: Royal Automobile Association of South Australia

talk.start.para: —I or someone in my family have been members of the Royal Automobile Association of South Australia over a continuous period of at least 33 years. On most occasions that I have ever required assistance from the RAA—and fortunately they have been few—the service has been more than satisfactory.

speech.para: Recently, as the member for Port Adelaide, I received some brief correspondence from the RAA on GST and petrol. The RAA expressed great concern about the way the government has applied the GST and the resulting failure of the government to meet its promise that petrol prices would not rise. They also argued that, before the GST was introduced, motorists were paying 44.14c per litre in excise on unleaded fuel, with the Commonwealth retaining 35.79c and the states taking 8.35c.

Under the GST, the RAA claimed the Commonwealth has increased its share of excise by 1.65c to 37.44c and the states are now receiving the GST instead of their fair share of the excise. The RAA further argued that, based on a fairly conservative regional price of 93c per litre, motorists were now paying 8.45c in GST as well as the 37.5c in excise. In other words, the RAA said that, before the GST, motorists were paying a total petrol tax of 44.14c; but now, under the GST, they are paying the increased total of 45.6c in petrol tax. They added that, even if the petrol retails at 89c per litre, the government still makes a gain of 1.4c a litre.

The RAA, on behalf of its 600,000 members in South Australia, supports the application of pressure by its members to meet the government's promise that petrol prices would not rise as a result of the GST. The RAA also believes that the federal government should freeze indexation of petrol excise during the next 12 months—I think the member for Makin did something about that in her office in relation to a petition yesterday—to avoid a substantial increase as a result of the inflationary spike predicted under the GST. The government's response to that suggestion would be illuminating indeed.

The correspondence from the RAA also stated that while collecting more tax from motorists—$858 million—the government has reduced road funding by $350 million. This is where I place a different emphasis to the RAA. I believe motorist organisations like the RAA and their associated interstate colleagues ought to have a far broader perspective on road funding, alternative forms of land transport and road safety to protect their valued membership. The RAA claims that, in addition to the $858 million the Commonwealth receives because of extra excise and indexation, the Commonwealth has also reduced road funding by $350 million. However, I find that far too limiting and simplistic an analysis which overlooks some important questions.

If that total of $1,208 million was used to get long distance trucks and their multiple trailers off the road and onto rail, I would support that expenditure. Getting a proportion of those trucks and trailers off the road and onto rail would certainly assist road safety and road costs for their 600,000 members. The RAA rightly concerns itself with the road user costs of its membership, but it should also concern itself with the prohibitive costs of road trauma in this country. As far as road trauma is concerned, the costs could be estimated at up to $10 billion, and they could be as high as $20 billion in this country when you take into account road deaths, debilitating injuries, health costs, skyrocketing insurance and so on. Taking into account the matter of damage to roads and resultant road maintenance costs simply adds to the problem.

The RAA must recognise that many of its members are deterred from exercising their rights on the roads for fear of what could happen. In fact, a number of people in my electorate will not go on the road any more because one of the access roads in my electorate now has the big trailers on it. There have been numerous very close calls and people are intimidated by the traffic and sometimes by the speed of those vehicles.

In conclusion, I support the general thrust of the RAA claims on behalf of its members. However, I would be more encouraged in matters concerning land transport if the RAA and its interstate colleagues took a far more responsible and broader perspective on behalf of their members with regard to all the costs associated with road usage, including not only road funding but also the real costs of road trauma and the use of alternative forms of transport to make the roads in this country safer than they are.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak with regard to the Australian Sports Medal recipients in my electorate of Cook. The Australian Sports Medal is a new national honour, established by the Office of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in recognition of outstanding achievement in sport. Awards to be made over the coming months are very timely, given the Sydney 2000 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

speech.para: The efforts of our grassroots giants in sport have helped Australia become a great sporting nation. They may be a coach, a club secretary or simply a parent who has donated years of effort in selling raffle tickets, organising the sausage sizzle or making sure that kids compete each week in clean uniforms. I would like to think that, when Australian athletes win Olympic gold, we remember our behind the scenes battlers in sports. The sports loving people of the Sutherland Shire are no different from those elsewhere. They are putting in week after week, year after year. One needs only to look at Seymour Shore Park any Saturday morning to get a feel for how sports loving my electorate is.

This is a `people's medal' and I am pleased to commend the following 12 people in the Cook electorate who have recently received the award. Margaret Corbett has been involved in Sutherland Shire netball for 50 years and has coached thousands of young athletes in that time. The Sutherland Shire, in which my electorate is based, has the greatest number of netball teams in any Australian local government area. Andrew Ettingshausen, captain of the Pepsi Sharks rugby league team, is much loved in my electorate. He is a great role model for young people. He has been awarded a sports medal as a representative of the entire team, which does a great deal of unrecognised charity work and junior league development work in the Sutherland Shire.

Bill Parsons, as head coach of the New South Wales Academy of Gymnastics, has trained more national gymnastic champions than any other coach in the sport. He received this medal for his contribution to gymnastics as a regional supervisor for the New South Wales Gymnastics Association for the area since 1982 and also as head coach at the New South Wales Academy of Gymnastics for 28 years. Stan Sherringham has been involved in Sutherland Shire athletics as an athlete, official, coach and administrator for some 61 years.

John Moodie formed the Sutherland Boys Cricket Team and the Sutherland Bowls Club, and has been involved in junior baseball and rugby league. The teams and clubs he formed as a young sportsman still thrive today. Greg Welch is regarded as the best all-round triathlete in the world and the only one to win in all divisions—iron man, Olympic, world long distance and world duathlon—in international competition. Peter Hadfield holds the record as Australia's most successful decathlete. He won nine consecutive national titles and represented Australia in Olympics and Commonwealth Games, where he won a silver medal.

Shirley Yardley has given tremendous support to soccer as secretary of the Miranda Magpies Soccer Club and member of the Sutherland Shire Junior Soccer Football Association. Ray Brennan has been a long-serving administrator of the Sylvania Youth Club, a manager and coach of the Sutherland Shire Junior Cricket Association and member of the Sydney Cricket Association Board.

Patricia Wade has given 40 years of voluntary service to the coaching, promotion and administration of hockey in the Sutherland Shire. I had the pleasure of awarding her medal in person at a recent ceremony. Ron Siddons has been a member of the Australian Surf Lifesaving Association for 50 years, has served as an inspector at Maroubra and Cronulla beaches for the last 42 years and has founded a learn to swim school for handicapped children called the Rainbow Club. Ron Riley, a three-time Olympic competitor with two silver medals, supports local hockey and is SOCOG's planner for the sport.

The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet informs me that there will most likely be other recipients, nominated not through my office but through their representative bodies. I would like also to make special mention of the gentlemen who comprised the local Sports Medal committee. I understand they had a difficult time whittling down the list of nominees from 29 to meet the cap that was imposed for each electorate. Michael Tynan, through his company Tynan's Motors, is an important benefactor to sports in the shire. Phil Bates is recognised as a leading authority on sports in the shire, and his input was also much appreciated.

I support all these people who have contributed so significantly to sport in my electorate for their long hours, Saturday morning after Saturday morning and on weekends generally, out there helping young people to perform to their utmost, including those who are never going to make it to the Olympics but just enjoy being out there and playing their sport.

talk.start.para: —I rise to express my anger at the way in which Telstra has again written off country people in my electorate. As you would be aware, Telstra has just recorded a $4 billion profit. Telstra CEO, Dr Ziggy Switkowski, is boasting that Telstra has again achieved double-digit growth in profits for its shareholders. But this enormous profit is achieved at the expense of country people. Yesterday, Telstra contractor Enetech sacked 100 employees from regional Victoria, including people from Bendigo, Ballarat, Geelong and Wodonga. Telstra did not provide additional work for this company and has caused the sackings. Only Telstra could be so insensitive as to announce a record profit of almost $4 billion on the same day that it caused 100 regional Victorian workers to lose their jobs.

speech.para: I would like to refer to yet another loss of service for country people. I am referring to Telstra's scrapping of its former practice of delivering regional phone directories to people in country areas free of charge. Telstra's neglected clients in this case have no effective recourse to justice from the telecommunications ombudsman. My constituent Mr Keith Walton lives at Sedgwick, a rural area south of Bendigo. He has written to me protesting against Telstra's scrapping last year of its formerly free delivery of the Bendigo regional telephone directory to him and to people in his area. Residents of urban Bendigo still receive free home delivery of the directory. Mr Walton can now obtain the directory only if he goes in person to the Strathfieldsaye Post Office—which he says represents a round trip of some 40 kilometres. He says that it can represent a return trip of around 80 kilometres for some of his neighbours who live further afield. He finds it particularly annoying that this delivery service had existed in the past but has now been withdrawn from him and his neighbours. He feels that he is being victimised because he lives in the country. City people have not suffered a similar loss of service.

The fact that Mr Walton has no recourse to justice has added insult to injury. He has written to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman requesting that it take up his complaint with Telstra. To his astonishment, this body—which is supposed to be the citizens' watchdog—has refused to receive his complaint, let alone act on it. In June this year, the TIO told him:

quote.para: The matter you have raised appears to be outside the jurisdiction of the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman. The TIO is unable to deal with matters relating to the commercial activities of a company. The decision made by Telstra not to deliver telephone directories falls under this category. The TIO is not in a position to direct Telstra to change its policy in relation to this.

speech.para: That response from a toothless watchdog is a betrayal of its charter and is in direct conflict with its own constitution, which states that it is a function of the TIO to:

quote.para: ... receive, investigate and facilitate resolution of complaints regarding the provision or supply (or the failure to provide or supply) of telecommunications services.

speech.para: Among these services, it specifically lists printed and electronic White Pages. This whole disgraceful story highlights once again how privatisation punishes and victimises country people. Telstra CEO, Dr Switkowski, brags of Telstra's double-digit increase in profits for his shareholders. This month, Dr Switkowski claimed:

quote.para: Customer service is the number one priority for the company and we have improved it this year and will continue to improve as we make the end to end experience for customers a good one.

speech.para: What nonsense! Telstra cannot afford to maintain the existing delivery of directories to country people once a year, yet it has thousands of dollars to maintain an Olympic Games slush fund to duchess the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and others with free Olympic Games tickets and other perks. It is little wonder that the privatisation of Telstra is on the nose in country Australia.

subdebateinfo.title: Broadhurst, Mr Horace
Australian Rugby League: Brisbane Broncos
Goods and Services Tax: Petrol Prices

subdebate.1.title: Australian Rugby League: Brisbane Broncos
Goods and Services Tax: Petrol Prices

talk.start.para: —I rise to mention a very special gentleman from my electorate, Mr Horace Broadhurst, who unfortunately lost his fight for life last week. Mr Broadhurst made many valuable contributions to the art world within my electorate but he was also well known to New South Wales opera's Sydney audiences as a fine baritone. He also travelled to and performed in New Guinea, Darwin and many other parts of Australia. In my electorate he was well known for his artistic work and also for the many sculptures that he did for local communities.

speech.para: Mr Broadhurst was a truly talented man. He said that he was going to teach me all his talents when I had finished with politics, and the saddest thing is that I will not be able to learn those many talents from anyone else. He was a very special man and I regret not taking up his offer a long time ago. I am interested in the art world, but I could never paint as well as he could so he was going to teach me the finer points. His wife, who is also very talented, will carry on within our community, making sure that his pupils are well looked after. I would like to pay my special respects to this special gentleman for the many contributions he made to my community. He will be greatly missed.

I would not be a true Queenslander if I did not take the time in the House today to mention the superb efforts of the Broncos in winning the ARL Grand Final last Sunday. They certainly displayed discipline and teamship, and proved that they are the best players in Australia. I would also like to pay tribute to Wayne Bennett, a gentleman whom I know. He is one of the best coaches in Australia, and at the same time is a very likeable gentleman. I would like also to thank Kevin Walters and Michael Hancock for their contributions to the sport. They have taken time to come into my electorate and talk to our local rugby league clubs, to our young people, to motivate them and pass on their many talents. Out of that, Tonie Carroll from my electorate went on to become a very good player, and I believe he has many years of good playing ahead of him. He is definitely putting on a very good display.

I would like to go back to Michael Hancock, because he is the only player who has survived since the inception of the Broncos back in 1988. He has announced his retirement and he is going to be sadly missed in the game. He was always there and always played as a team person.

I would also like to mention Darren Lockyer. He is another young fellow who I have seen come up through the ranks. He is only 23 and I know he is going to really excel in the future, although I do not think he could do much better than to win the Churchill Medal. I would like to congratulate him on that top effort and urge him to keep up the good work. I look forward to supporting the team for many years to come and to them winning the grand final again next year.

In the couple of minutes I have left I would also like to agree with the member for McPherson that our state Premier, Mr Beattie, should be called, as she called him, `Petrol tax Pete.' We all know that the world price of petrol dictates whether the price goes up or down. I find his comments very hypocritical since he is the beneficiary of the price increase—the higher the price of petrol goes up, the more that goes back into the state coffers.

He has been saying about petrol prices that the federal government should freeze the CPI indexation. If we do that, he is telling us not to give pensioners an increase in their pensions, because that is where the money from this excise goes. It goes to health, hospitals and education but, more importantly, to helping people out in our community who are on public benefits. If we index that then we have to index pensions. I am going to ask him right here and now: is that what he is telling us to do? I ask him to put the extra money that he is making back into the health and education system within Queensland, to put his money where his mouth is and leave the pensioners alone and put the money back into the state's needs.

talk.start.para: —One of the great dilemmas of government these days relates to being able to tackle the vexed problem of unemployment. If you look at capitalism, stretching back to when it originated in the Netherlands in the 1600s, it has probably always been true that capitalism has been challenged by `small l' liberals all through those 400 years, whether they are on the left of politics, the centre left or the centre right. Nevertheless, capitalism has always been made accountable. But that is probably not true of the last 10 or 20 years when capitalism has been reigning unfettered and unchallenged.

speech.para: This morning people were taking note of a report called Age counts, dealing with the vexed problem of mature age unemployment. Tim Colebatch in the Age the other week pointed out, after reading the McClure report, that 22 per cent of working age Australians receive social security benefits. When I get up in this parliament and I say that 700,000 people are unemployed, no-one challenges me, because that is right. When I get up and say that 700,000 people are underemployed, no-one challenges me, but I do not know whether that is right. The real problem is that no-one else does either. When I get up in this House and say that 700,000 people in this country are hidden unemployed as well, no-one challenges me. I do not know whether that is true either.

That is the real problem: data about unemployment in this country is simply non-existent. If we continue to go on instituting false solutions to this vexed problem we will simply harm people. Many people have said that the mature aged have been devastated by their loss of positions, and that is certainly true. The way we treat mature aged people who have lost their jobs in this country is simply terrible. The discrimination is simply unforgivable.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Allowances and Entitlements
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1282)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Australian Defence Force (ADF) identified some 80 separate personnel allowances and entitlements that are potentially affected by the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax (GST); if so, what are the details of these allowances and entitlements.
(2) As a result of the introduction of the GST, what is the estimated increase in (a) rents paid by personnel for subsidised housing and (b) the cost of subsidised meals in service messes.

(3) Is the ADF committed to the principle that personnel should not be financially disadvantaged by the impost of the GST; if so, what measures will be taken to address the negative impacts of the GST.
(4) What is the estimated annual cost to the Budget of making appropriate adjustments to personnel allowances and entitlements to offset increased costs arising from the GST.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Defence has identified approximately 80 different allowances and entitlements paid to civilian and military personnel. The introduction of the GST, and any consequential increase in the cost of goods and services, will have no affect on the purchasing power of Defence personnel.

Most allowances paid to Defence personnel attract income tax. The buying power of these allowances will not be affected by the introduction of the GST. Defence personnel will benefit from considerable income tax cuts and consequently will receive an increase in the `after tax' amount of these allowances. This will cover any increase in the cost of goods and services.

In addition, all allowance rates are reviewed on an annual or biannual basis. These reviews will take into account the total impact of the New Tax System, including the abolition of wholesale sales tax, on the purchasing power of allowances. Recently, travelling allowance rates have been reviewed. The new rates include an adjustment for the anticipated impact of the GST.

Where allowances are paid to enable personnel to purchase specific goods and services, the rate of these allowances will be amended by application of the Australian Bureau of Statistics GST-inclusive CPI.
(2) (a) None.
(b) Subsidised meal charges have been adjusted to take into account movements in the food component of the CPI and the impact of the GST. Increases in meal charges range from 6.25% to 8.45%.

(3) Defence is committed to the principle that personnel should not be financially disadvantaged by the impact of the GST. Defence has conducted a comprehensive review of personnel entitlements and allowances to determine the impact of the New Tax System. The review has found that the GST will not impact negatively on personnel entitlements. In addition, a Defence booklet providing personnel with information about the treatment of Defence allowances and entitlements under the New Tax System has been distributed to all personnel.
(4) None.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Could he update his answer to question No. 6 (Hansard, 30 November 1998, page 995) on the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in respect of its last meeting held in Melbourne in March 2000.
(2) When and where will the next meeting be held.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) The Commonwealth's written report, placed before the 24 March 2000 meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, included the following human rights issues:
. the Draft Declaration of the Rights of Indigenous Peoples;
. the Optional Protocol to the Torture Convention;
. the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women;
. possible optional protocols to the Convention on the Rights of the Child;
. the ILO Convention on the Elimination of the Worst Forms of Child Labour;
. complaints under International Communications procedures; and
. reporting under International Communications procedures.
Other matters included:
. Disability Discrimination Legislation and Disability Standards;
. the reform of the Human Rights Equal Opportunity Commission;
. cooperative arrangements with the States;
. the SCAG Working Group on Human Rights;
. the Non-Government Organisations Forum on domestic human rights;
. the Decade of Human Rights Education;
. the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties Report on the Convention on the Rights of the Child;
. Age Discrimination;
. the National Action Plan on human rights;
. legal reform in HIV/AIDS (Fourth National Strategy);
. the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) report, “Pregnant & Productive: It's a right not a privilege to work while pregnant”; and
. the HREOC inquiry on the access of disabled and older Australians to electronic commerce and on-line services.
Victoria also placed mandatory sentencing laws and Aboriginal justice issues on the agenda.

(b) The Commonwealth's items were placed on the agenda in the context of its Human Rights paper. This paper serves to inform States and Territories about the activities of the Commonwealth in the human rights area. Matters raised in the paper were noted by State and Territory Attorneys-General.

The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General noted the views expressed by various Ministers on mandatory sentencing. Ministers noted the Officers' paper on Aboriginal justice issues and reported on progress in implementing Aboriginal justice plans. Ministers also gave instructions relating to the settling of an agenda for the proposed joint meeting with the Ministerial Council for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.
(2) The next meeting is scheduled to be held in Brisbane on 27/28 July 2000.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force: Ground Defence Reserve Group
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1621)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) What are the major conditions of service that apply to the RAAF's Ground Defence Reserve Group.
(2) What is the Group's (a) target strength nationally and (b) current number of serving personnel.
(3) What changes, if any, have been made to the conditions of service for the Group since 1996.
(4) Are any personnel attached to the Group currently deployed overseas; if so, (a) how many and (b) in what countries.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Members of the Ground Defence Reserve Group are:

subdebateinfo.title: Fiji and the Solomon Islands: Diplomatic Initiatives
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1625)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) What diplomatic initiatives involving the nations of the South Pacific has the Australian Government carried out in the light of the attempted coups in Fiji and the Solomon Islands.

(2) Will the Government consider immediately organising a meeting of the Security Committee of the South Pacific Forum in order to discuss developments in Fiji and the Solomon Islands and determine a coordinated response from the South Pacific Forum.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

quote.para: (1) Australia's diplomatic missions in the Pacific have consulted closely with host country governments on the situation in Fiji and Solomon Islands, and Australia's reaction to the crisis, and encouraged Pacific Island governments to respond in similarly strong terms. Our Pacific posts have also approached host governments seeking their cooperation to deny George Speight and his supporters entry to countries of the region, should they decide to travel outside Fiji.

(2) The annual meeting of the Forum Regional Security Committee (FRSC), which was to have taken place in Suva from 13 to 15 June, was held in Port Vila, Vanuatu from 13 to 15 July 2000. Reference points for the meeting were the crises in Fiji and the Solomon Islands and the report of a study on enhancing Pacific security undertaken by Professsor Ron Crocombe, a University of the South Pacific academic based in the Cook Islands. The meeting identified a range of options to address security concerns in the region, including preventive diplomacy measures, which would build on the 1997 Aitutaki Declaration on Regional Security Cooperation. These options have been forwarded to the Leaders' meeting of the South Pacific Forum in Kiribati in October and may also be considered by other Forum ministerial meetings in the interim.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice on 8 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Under what scheme did the Commonwealth make payments to National Textile Workers who lost their entitlements due to the insolvency of that company.
(2) What criteria were used to assess eligibility for this assistance.
(3) For each State and Territory how many workers who have lost their employee entitlements through company insolvency have received assistance on the same terms as National Textiles.

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr Reith
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Commonwealth payments to the employees of National Textiles to contribute to their employee entitlements have been drawn from the Regional Assistance Program and the Employee Entitlements Support Scheme.

(2) To the extent that the payments were drawn from the Employee Entitlements Support Scheme, the criteria used were those applied to applicants under the Scheme. These are that the employees were lawfully employed in Australia; that they are not an “excluded employee” within the meaning of the Operational Arrangements for the Scheme; that their employment was terminated by their employer or insolvency practitioner in lieu of their employer on or since 1 January 2000, because the employer has become insolvent or has otherwise been under external administration, and there has been a Commencement of Employer Insolvency (whether before or after the termination); and that they are owed certain employee entitlements by their former employer. The decision to provide an additional payment from the National Projects component of the Regional Assistance Programme was made in a manner consistent with the case by case basis by which such projects are considered. In this case, the Government had regard to the circumstances of the textile industry and the company's location in a disadvantaged regional area.

(3) As at 4 August 2000, in addition to the employees of National Textiles, safety net payments had been made for 214 claimants under the Employee Entitlements Support Scheme. By State, these claimants were located as follows:

However, other than the payments that the New South Wales Government made to the employees of National Textiles, no state government has matched any of the monetary assistance provided to these former employees by the Federal Government under the Employee Entitlements Support Scheme. The Federal Government has continued to call on state governments to demonstrate that they have not turned their backs on workers, and to participate in the Employee Entitlements Support Scheme.
The Howard Government is the first to take serious steps towards addressing this problem. Labor languished in Government for 13 years, without implementing a satisfactory solution.

The onus is on employers to pay their employees' entitlements, and the Howard Government has successfully amended the corporations laws to strengthen this requirement. However, there should also be a safety net in place, and the wider community should share the responsibility for this.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has Australia previously played a prominent role in UN Social Development Conferences and have Australian Ministers always represented Australia at this forum.

(2) Does the Government have a commitment to the resolution of outstanding social issues including massive poverty, low life expectancy, the high prevalence of diseases such as tuberculosis and AIDS, the crisis concerning refugees and the prevalence of discrimination based on ethnicity and gender in many of the poorer countries of the world.
(3) If so, why has Australia decided not to have any ministerial representation at the UN World Summit on Social Development to be held on 26 to 30 June 2000.
(4) What is the reason for the reduction in Australia's formerly prominent participation in these UN conferences.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) There have been two UN Social Development Conferences, the World Summit for Social Development at Copenhagen in 1995, and the five year follow up to this Summit at Geneva in June 2000. Then Prime Minister, Paul Keating represented Australia at the Copenhagen Summit. Australia has continued to play a prominent role. In August 1999 Australia submitted a comprehensive report on its implementation of the outcome of the Copenhagen Summit. In the lead up to the 2000 Geneva Summit, Australia actively participated in the relevant preparatory meetings. Australia was represented by the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations at Geneva, Mr Les Luck, at the Geneva Summit this year.

(2) The Australian Government maintains a strong focus on poverty alleviation in the Australian aid program and invests significantly in the areas of health, education and gender equity. It also provides humanitarian and emergency assistance to those exposed to human suffering and material destruction as a result of disasters and emergencies.

In 2000-01, expenditure on social infrastructure and services is estimated to be around $646.3 million, representing about 40% of total aid program expenditure. This figure includes spending on education and training, health and population programs, water supply and sanitation, government and civil society.

The high prevalence of disease in developing countries is a major concern to the Australian government. In 2000-01, the Government estimates expenditure of $170 million of direct health assistance to developing countries. Australia's health aid targets those groups most at risk and focuses on improving basic health care and services through simple, cost effective methods of prevention and treatment. In 2000-01, 25% of all health aid is expected to be spent on infectious disease and STD control.

The Australian Government considers that improving outcomes for women is essential to achieve poverty alleviation. The aid program provides assistance to increase women's access to education, health care and economic resources; to encourage women's participation and leadership in decision-making at all levels; to promote human rights of women and to eliminate discrimination against women. The aid program is also giving increased attention to activities that address violence against women. In 2000-01, Australia will spend an estimated $40 million on activities in which the promotion of gender equity is the main objective. A further $380 million is expected to be spent on activities in which gender equity considerations are significant.

The Australian aid program also provides considerable support for humanitarian assistance. In 1999-00, Australia responded to the humanitarian crisis in East Timor by providing an additional $60 million. Australia's contribution to emergency and humanitarian programs in 2000-01 is estimated to be $107.2 million. This includes support for refugees, internally displaced people and other vulnerable groups, as well as for landmine action programs, sanitation and resettlement assistance and human rights monitoring.

(3) The Australian Government did not believe Ministerial participation at the meeting in Geneva from 26 June to 1 July 2000 would have represented optimal use of the Government's resources, especially during a sitting week when important issues of national governance needed to be addressed. Australia's interests were comprehensively promoted by the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations at Geneva, Mr Les Luck.

(4) Australia has not reduced its level of participation in the issues addressed by the UN Social Development Conferences. Australia was more than adequately represented at the Geneva Summit - which was a 5 year review of the initial Summit at Copenhagen - by Ambassador Luck..

subdebateinfo.title: Fiji and the Solomon Islands: Australian Initiatives
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1666)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) What positive outcomes were achieved from Mr Downer's visits to Solomon Islands and Fiji.
(2) What role will Australia take in the resolution of these crises.
(3) Were there any undertakings as to Australia's role made as a consequence of these visits.
(4) Will Mr Downer make a comprehensive statement to the House in relation to his visits to Solomon Islands and Fiji.
(5) Will Mr Downer arrange for the House to have a full debate on the crisis in the Solomon Islands and Fiji.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) My visits to Solomon Islands and Fiji, as a member of the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group delegation, enabled me to convey to leaders in the respective countries the need for democratic and constitutional settlements to both crises.

(2) Australia has consistently urged all the parties, in both Fiji and Solomon Islands, to identify peaceful and constitutional means of addressing their respective concerns. I have made Australia's abhorrence of unconstitutional actions plain to all concerned, and have warned the various parties of the risk of international disapprobation, including smart sanctions, if they persisted in operating outside the rule of law.

(3) Yes, in the case of Solomon Islands I advised that Australia would provide further generous assistance to underpin a peace process, if a democratic resolution of the political crisis was achieved and if a ceasefire between the militant factions was negotiated. I made it clear to those I met in Solomon Islands and Fiji that, without a swift return to democratic government and the rule of law, Australia's support and friendship could not be taken for granted.

(4) The Government's policy on both crises has been stated in detail to the House by the Prime Minister, the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs Mr Moore, and by myself, in comprehensive responses to a range of questions and in statements on 29, 30 and 31 May, and on 6, 7 and 8 June. To date, and for the supplementary information of Parliamentarians, I have also issued 8 media releases on the situation in Fiji in recent weeks and another 8 on the situation in Solomon Islands.
(5) A full debate in the House on the crisis in Solomon Islands and Fiji has already taken place. It began on 19 June and concluded on 26 June 2000.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation: Cultural Property Initiatives
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1674)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, upon notice, on 26 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) On his forthcoming visit to Britain, will he ask his British counterpart, culture Secretary Chris Smith, for the return of all Aboriginal remains from British museums and other institutions; if so, on what grounds will he argue for the return of the remains.
(2) Is he able to say whether there is British legislation through which the return of the Aboriginal remains would be facilitated.
(3) Would those laws also facilitate the repatriation of the Parthenon Marbles to Greece.

(4) Will he raise with his British counterpart the failure of the British Government to become a party to the Unesco Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property (Paris, 1970).
(5) Is he able to say whether British museums will not repatriate items unless a government-to-government agreement is in place; if so, will he pursue such an agreement.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The return of Indigenous human remains is a complex and sensitive issue. While I have responsibility for collections held in Australian museums, the return of Indigenous human remains held in collections overseas are the responsibility of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron.

The Prime Minister raised the issue of the return of Indigenous human remains in his discussions with Prime Minister Tony Blair during Australia Week in Britain. The Prime Ministers issued the following joint statement on 4 July 2000 outlining their governments' approach to this issue:

“The Australian and British governments agree to increase efforts to repatriate human remains to Australian Indigenous communities. In doing this, the governments recognise the special connection that Indigenous people have with ancestral remains, particularly where there are living descendants.

The Australian government appreciates the efforts already made by the British government and institutions in relation to assisting the return of human remains of significance to Australian Indigenous communities. We agree that the way ahead in this area is a co-operative approach between our governments. Our governments recognise that there is a range of significant issues to be addressed in order to facilitate the repatriation of Indigenous human remains. Addressing these issues requires a co-ordinated long-term approach by governments involving Indigenous communities and collecting institutions. Consultation will be undertaken with Indigenous organisations as part of developing any new co-operative arrangements.

Significant efforts have already been undertaken by individuals and particular organisations in this area. More research is required to identify Indigenous human remains held in British collections. Extensive consultation must also be undertaken to determine the relevant traditional custodians, their aspirations regarding the treatment of the remains and a means for addressing these.

The governments agree to encourage the development of protocols for the sharing of information between British and Australian institutions and Indigenous people. In this respect we welcome the initiative of the British Natural History Museum which has catalogued the 450 Indigenous human remains in its collection and provided this information to the Australian government.

We endorse the repatriation of Indigenous human remains wherever possible and appropriate from both public and private collections. We note that several British institutions have already negotiated agreements with Indigenous communities for the release of significant remains. In particular, Edinburgh University, following extensive consultation with the Australian government and Indigenous organisations, has recently completed repatriation of a large collection of remains.
Our governments look forward to continuing to address this issue in a co-operative and constructive spirit.”

(2), (3) and (5) I understand that there are legislative constraints in Britain on the return of collection items, including human remains, from certain government funded institutions. There have been cases of repatriation of Indigenous human remains from British institutions in circumstances in which the legislative constraints do not apply, such as the recent repatriation of the large Edinburgh University collection.
(4) The Australian Government does not advise the British Government about its decisions in relation to international conventions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 28 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations contained in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 June 2000 which states that Sydney's aircraft noise-sharing plan is under threat of collapse in the wake of claims by international pilots that the use of the east-west runway should be curtailed because of potentially dangerous cross winds.

(2) Has the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Association (IFALPA) put a `red star' on Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (KSA) because the east-west runway is allowed to be used in cross winds of up to 25 knots.
(3) Is the IFALPA threatening to put a further
`black star' on KSA if the airport is further upgraded to permit the east-west runway to be used in conditions of up to 25 knots.
(4) Do international rules for operating aircraft permit aircraft movement in 25 knot cross winds, whereas a 15 knot limit is set for noise abatement purposes.
(5) If the standard put forward by the IFALPA is accepted, should the third runway be governed by the same rules.
(6) Is the third runway at KSA approximately 100m shorter than the east-west runway.
(7) If the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) must becompromised in favour of the safety findings,has KSA exceeded its environmental sustainable development threshold.
(8) Is the environmental sustainability of KSA predicated on the LTOP.
(9) Must a finding that the operational plan of KSA is unsafe be measured by his gazetted LTOP.

(10) Notwithstanding the findings on safety by the IFALPA, is he bound to his gazetted LTOP and that this responsibility is not mitigated by the belated findings of alleged aircraft safety after the gazettal of the LTOP.
(11) Did he consider the matters raised by the IFALPA when the LTOP was proclaimed.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The International Federation of Air Line Pilots' Association (IFALPA) wrote to me on 12 June 2000 in relation to a number of concerns with Sydney Airport. The letter indicated that it believes that in light of its concerns it `...has no option but to designate Sydney Airport as Class 2 Serious Deficiency Red Star...'.
(3) In its letter to me, IFALPA stated that if no action is taken on the matters raised a Class 3 Critical Deficiency Black Star will be applied to Sydney Airport.

(4) I am advised that International rules do not prescribe crosswind limits other than the limit to which each aircraft is certificated. There exists an international recommendation that noise abatement procedures should not be required in adverse weather conditions, such as crosswinds exceeding 15 knots. However, it is common for international airports to operate in crosswinds exceeding 15 knots.

(5) In response to the IFALPA letter, I wrote to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) on 20 June 2000 asking that it examine the issues raised by IFALPA. The implications of making changes to crosswind limits, including whether they should be applied to all or only specified runways, are matters being covered as part of this review.
(6) I am advised that the physical length of the east-west runway is 2529 metres. The length of the third runway is 2438 metres.
(7), (8) and (9) The question of the extent to which noise sharing would be affected by any change in the crosswind limitations is now being examined by Airservices Australia.
(10) The Government remains committed to noise sharing at Sydney Airport but safety is our first priority.
(11) The crosswind limit on runways at Sydney Airport has been 25 knots since 1989. LTOP,which was introduced in 1997, was predicated on no long term change being made to that crosswind limit.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Following the Report of the Independent Review Panel for the End of War List for Vietnam what action has the Government taken to revise (a) the quota system for operational awards, (b) the process for recommending operational awards including the desirability of an Independent Assessment Panel within Defence and (c) the Order of Wearing of Australian Honours and Awards.
(2) If the Government has not reviewed these matters since the Report, will he undertake to do so; if not, why not.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) The quota system for gallantry and distinguished awards for operational service was referred by the Government to the Interdepartmental Committee on Honours and Awards to Defence Force Personnel (IDC) following the report of the Independent Review Panel of the End of War List Vietnam. The IDC recommended quotas be retained.

(b) As a result of the IDC recommendation, the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) considers that a practical result can be produced by using quotas as a basis from which to start when assessing operational lists, but the quota should not limit the number of awards that may be conferred. Consequently, there is no limit on the number of nominations which may be submitted to headquarters, Australian Defence Force, from an operational area. This contrasts with the policy in place during the Vietnam conflict. The success of any nomination under this revised procedure then lies in the strength of the citation when assessed against the relevant medals regulations. Prior to the CDF making his final decision, recommendations will be assessed by Single Service committees. This system was used for the first operational list from East Timor in February 2000 and is considered to have been successful in its application.

(c) The Order of Wearing of Australian Honours and Awards (Order of Wearing) was also referred by the Government to the IDC. It was the view of the IDC that the Order of Wearing is important and should be maintained in its current form. The IDC was unable to establish what purpose would be served by further clarification in the document of its purpose. The document already clearly states its purpose.
(2) Under the circumstances detailed at part (1), no further reviews are considered necessary.
